_header: The more I go the farther I am behind
_description: The first stanza (ababbcc) of ‘Tyed with a Line’ (5410), standing alone or directly following 5534.

BodFair16.First Lines:
The more I goo the ferther I am behindeThe ferther behinde the ner
                    my wayes ende…
BodFair16.Last Lines:
…Is thys ffortune not I or infortuneThough I go lowse tyed am
                    I with a lune (sic)
BodFair16.Facsimiles:
Norton-Smith,  John. 
             “Introduction.” 
             Bodleian Library MS Fairfax 16.
         London: Scolar Press, 1979.
BodFair16.Editions:
South,  Helen Pennock. 
             “The Question of Halsam.” 
             PMLA
         50 (1935): 362-71: 362.
Sisam,  Celia,  and  Kenneth Sisam, eds.  
             The Oxford Book of Medieval English Verse.
         Oxford: Clarendon, 1970: 385-6.

CULFf16.Transcription:
The more I goo the further am I be hyndeThe further be hynde the nere
                    my vayis endeThe more I seke the worsse con I fyndeThe lyghtere leve
                    the lothere to wendeIs thus fortune not I or ellis in fortuneThaugh I
                    goo lewse tyed am I with a lyne
CULFf16.Facsimiles:
Beadle,  Richard,  and  Alfred E. B. Owen.  
             The Findern Manuscript: Cambridge University Library MS. F.1.6.
         London: Scolar Press, 1977.

BLAdd5465.Note: With music in two voices credited to William Newark.
BLAdd5465.Editions:
Pearce,  Charles William. 
             A Collection of Songs and Madrigals by English Composers of the close
                of the 15th Century.
Plainsong and Medieval Music Society.
         London: Quaritch, 1891: [M] 19-22.
Stevens,  John,
                        ed.  
             Music and Poetry in the Early Tudor Court.
         London: Methuen, 1961: 352.

BLAdd16165.First Lines:
Þe more I go þe firþer I am behyndeþe firre
                    behynde þe nere my weyes eend…
BLAdd16165.Last Lines:
…Is þis fortune not I or infortuneþoughe I go loose
                    I tyde am with a leyne
BLAdd16165.Note:
Together with 5534 as if a
                    single text of two stanzas.
BLAdd16165.Attributed Title:
And filowynge begynnen two verses made in wyse of balade by Halsham Esquyr
                    (f. 244)

BLHar7333.First Lines:
Þe more I good þe forþere I am be hyndeÞe more
                    I seche þe worse kan I fynde…
BLHar7333.Last Lines:
…Is þis ffortune not I or In fortuneÞaughe I goo
                    loosse I tyed am with a loynge
BLHar7333.Note:
Follows, as if part of the same poem, 3504, both introduced by the heading ‘Halsam Squiere Made thes
                    ij balades’.
BLHar7333.Editions:
Wright,  Thomas,  and  James Orchard Halliwell-Phillipps, eds.  
             Reliquiae Antiquae.
         2 vols. London: Smith, 1845: 1.234.
Flügel,  Ewald. 
             “Kleinere Mitteilungen aus handschriften: Maister Benet’s
                Christmas Game.” 
             Anglia
         14 (1892): 463-6: 463.

BLHar7578.Transcription:
The more I gooth the ferthr I am be hindeThe ferthir behinde the nere
                    my weres endeThe more I seche the werse can I fyndeThe light leue the
                    lother for to wendeThe better I serue the more oute of myndeIs this
                    fortune not I or in fortuneThough I goo loos tyed am y with a
                    loynne

HunHM144.First Lines:
The further I goo the more behyndeThe more behynde the ner my weyes
                    ende…
HunHM144.Last Lines:
…Though I goo loose I am teyde with a lyneIs hit fortune or
                    Infortune thus I fyne
HunHM144.Note:
First stanza only; immediately follows 2729 and 5534, as if part of same text; ends
                    ‘Explicit.’
HunHM144.Editions:
Furnivall,  Frederick James. 
             “Chaucer and Lydgate Fragments.” 
             Notes and Queries
         5th ser. 9 (1878): 342-3: 342.
Bühler,  Kurt. 
             “Lydgate’s Horse, Sheep and Goose and Huntington MS HM
                144.” 
             Modern Language Notes
         55 (1940): 563-69: 567.

HunEL26A13.First Lines:
Þe more I go þe firþer I am behindeÞe
                    firþer behinde þe nerre my weyes eonde…
HunEL26A13.Last Lines:
…Is þis fortune not I or infortuneþoughe I go loose
                    I tyed am with youre lvne
HunEL26A13.Note:
Follows 5534; not 5397 as given in Hamer (1995)
XHamer,  Richard. 
             A Manuscript Index to the Index of Middle English Verse.
         London: British Library, 1995.

YaleBei365.Transcription:
The ferder I goo the mor be hyndThe mor be hynd the more my weyis
                    ȝyndThe mor I seke the wers can I ffyndThe trewer I serve the
                    ferder owt of myndThow I god losse ȝyt am I teyid with a lyneThus
                    ffortyn or on ffortyn thys I ffynd
